If goods or services are exchanged directly for goods or services, then there is no trade deficit, by definition, even if the parties have arranged to perform at different times.

If there is a credit storing value, then the parties are not employing a full barter system.
No, that is not a barter system.
Oh, okay. My bad.

When a person voluntarily exchanges money for a good or service, that person is not harmed; he gets something of value in return. A trade deficit happens every time you use money to buy something. A barter system has no trade deficits; they are a *feature* of a currency system. https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1078632205210058752 …

Yes, it’s a problem, especially for candidates like me who work outside the political establishment and receive little PAC support. But there’s not a good constitutional solution.

No, they both support a dysfunctional process. Limits need to comply with the Constitution. More important would be to change laws, like straight-ticket voting and unequal ballot access, that prevent competition.
Both major parties are dysfunctional. In Michigan, our laws make it practically impossible to be elected outside these two parties.
Because they are blinded by power.

I vote yes more than half the time. The Constitution limits federal power; many items should be handled by states. Leaders also tightly control what’s voted on; zero unscreened amendments were allowed this term. The solution is to open up the process and allow real deliberation.

There will be a vote tonight on an appropriations bill known as a continuing resolution, or CR, to spend hundreds of billions of dollars and fund unconstitutional programs. The government will continue to grow recklessly and burden future generations. I’ll be voting no.

Yes, there are exceptions to the rule, e.g., items a government needs to operate, but such exceptions do not distinguish international trade from other trade.

International trade is like other trade in that it takes place between people or businesses, not countries. Believing that X country is buying/selling Y product from/to the United States likely leads to more mistakes in economic analysis than any other misconception about trade.

Different article/time period/issue and also misleading. That one *is* about a vote, but not specifically Flint. The legislation allowed around 100 areas—including some whole states—to qualify for special funding, regardless of current circumstances, and it excluded my district.

This headline (and article) is often used to mislead people. 1. It’s not related to a vote, just a statement. 2. Pres. Obama is the person who denied the request for federal disaster aid because it wasn’t authorized by law, and I agreed with him that the law did not authorize it.
